characters: MY FATHER WAS AN EXCEPTIONAL MAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MUSIC CUE: "DON'T WORRY, BE HAPPY" by Bobby McFerrin play

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We pan across a room filled with caskets.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: People somberly walk into a church.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see the signs outside of various funeral homes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We close in on a HEADSTONE that reads: "DEATH AT A FUNERA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ASIAN PALL BEARERS carry a coffin into a church.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We push in on another headstone that reads: "Starring Chr Rock". As we push through the cemetery, we see various co stars' names chiseled on headstones. We see a fleet of hearses driving through a cemetery.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see a FLORIST making a funeral arrangement.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE UP of another headstone that has the director's nam chiseled on it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MUSIC CUE: The music fades out. TIGHT SHOT on AARON (CHRIS ROCK) thirties, dressed in a b suit and tie. He looks straight ahead with a somber expre The camera pulls back to reveal he is watching FOUR UNDER (INCLUDING BRIAN) place a coffin on a raised platform.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The living room has been prepared for the funeral service several rows of chairs laid out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Would you like to see... Aaron nods his head "yes", as BRIAN begins to open the co Aaron crosses to the coffin. There's a dramatic moment as Aaron moves to the coffin an braces himself for what he's about to see. The coffin ope Aaron stares long and hard at the body.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brian... who is that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Excuse me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who is this man I'm looking at? 'Cause it's not my father.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you sure?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you asking me if I'm sure I know what my father looks like?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: People make mistakes in times of grief.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Man, look at the damn body! Brian peers into the coffin. We see it's an ASIAN MAN.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh shit! The other undertakers look embarrassed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on, Brian. You know what my father looks like. He used to take you to little league.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry, man. I got a little nervous. This almost never happens.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's happened before?! You mean this is a normal thing?... This isn't Burger King. You can't just mess up my order.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think I know where he is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You think?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Close up of the casket opening. People look confused. The looking into the coffin speaks Chinese with subtitles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's not my father.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I better .,see my dad in this coffin in an hour, or you're going to take his place. The undertakers pick up the coffin and shuffle out awkwar

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't worry. I'll get him, man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You do that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My people, my people, my people...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aaron enters the bedroom. His wife, MICHELLE, also thirti attractive, is putting on makeup with a thermometer hangi her mouth. Aaron stands looking dumbfounded.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They brought the wrong body. Can you believe that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (muffled because of

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The wrong body?! Do they know where he is?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They think so. They're getting him now. The thermometer beeps and Michelle removes it from her mo

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I told you not to use Marshals. But no, you wanted to keep it in the neighborhood. I know Swartz costs a little more, but at least they know where the bodies are. Michelle writes something down on a piece of paper as Aar crosses the room and sits on the bed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You were right. Please don't rub it in, not today. I've got so much to worry about. Michelle gets up and heads to the bathroom as Aaron takes some index cards and looks them over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dad insisted on having the funeral here, Mom's crying all the time, Ryan didn't help with anything, not like he ever does! Plus my eulogy sucks. I can't wait until this day is over.

dialogues.speaker: MICHELLE, (O.S.)
dialogues.text: Oh come on, honey. I'm sure it's not that bad.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If it is, at least Dad's too dead to hear it. Michelle exits the bathroom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Honey, it's going to be fine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It doesn't matter what I write. All anybody's going to be thinking is "why isn't Ryan doing the eulogy? Even I'm going to be thinking it. She holds him close.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Baby, you're the oldest. You have to do the eulogy. Besides, I think you're just as good a writer as your brother. You just need to let someone read your book. Aaronlooks away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Soon. It's not ready to be read yet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sure it's fine. Once the funeral's over, and everything dies

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aaron gives her a look.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry. Look, once this is all over, you know your mom's thinking about selling the house, so you know we've got to get out.of here. Aaron looks a little uncomfortable and heads to the bathr

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You called them, right? Silence from Aaron in the next room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aaron?... You put the down payment on the condo, right?

dialogues.speaker: AARON, (O.C.)
dialogues.text: I said I'd take care of it and I'll take care of it. Michelle looks frustrated and crosses into the bathroom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aaron is at the mirror.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You better, because I can't live with your mother anymore. I've done my time, now it's time for your brother to take over. From now on, it's only Christmas and birthdays for us. Once we move, we can concentrate on your writing and our baby. Michelle gets down on her knees and starts unzipping Aaro pants. Aaron pulls back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, hey, hey. Are you serious? We have to do this today? Michelle is still on the ground.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. Today's the last day of this cycle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can I at least find the body first?

dialogues.speaker: DAY
dialogues.text: We see NORMAN'S CAR speeding along the freeway.

dialogues.speaker: DAY
dialogues.text: NORMAN, black, slightly heavier and riddled with anxiety, driving. His friend, DEREK, an attractive, white, clean c doctor, rides in the passenger seat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I hate funerals. It's all death, death, death.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't think funerals are designed for anybody to really like.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't want a regular funeral. When I die, I want people to celebrate my life.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Death at a Funeral 02/6/09

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not me. I want it to be the saddest day ever. I want the stock market to stop. Schools to close. And no garbage pick-up. Derek starts to light a cigarette.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You still smoke?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You used to smoke.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I used to piss my pants too, but I stopped. The only thing I want black is my skin. At least open the window. Derek opens the window very slightly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've got enough problems of my own to deal with.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah? What problems?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I told you... About the rash...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Got to use condoms.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: .on my hand...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Still got to use condoms.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look at it. Norman pulls up his sleeve and makes Derek look at his wr but he doesn't take a great deal of interest.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's not a rash.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know, but it doesn't look right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, damn. Norman continues to drive. Derek continues to smoke.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you hate funerals so much why are you coming?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know why.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on, man, leave Elaine alone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't. She's the one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So you're going to win her back over a dead body?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If I have to.

dialogues.speaker: DAY
dialogues.text: ELAINE, very attractive, 27, and her boyfriend OSCAR, whi are driving along wearing funeral attire. Oscar looks qui anxious as he keeps his eyes firmly on the road.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you okay?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, just a little nervous...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: About seeing my dad?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I just don't think I've ever been so openly hated by anyone before.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He doesn't hate you. He just loved Derek.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Great. That makes me feel much better.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At least you know it's not you, so try not to get so nervous when he's around.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't help it. He puts me on edge. I feel like I owe him money.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's going to be more.concerned that his brother-in-law just died. He won't be focused on you. Anyway, when I tell him we're getting married, he'll have to accept you. Elaine takes his hand. As they exchange a loving look, Os takes his eyes off the road for just a brief moment. Sudd there's a BUMP!!! And we see a bicyclist flying over Osca car. Oscar screeches to a halt. They jump out of the car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh my God. Are you okay? The guy gets up. He's fine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, I'm fine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you sure? Is anything broken? I'm so sorry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was my fault. I ran a light. Oscar starts hyperventilating.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I could have killed you. What if you had cracked your head open? I'd have blood on my hands! Elaine shakes him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oscar, calm down!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You heard the man, he ran a light. Come on, let's get out of here before he wants to sue. She grabs him and pulls him into the car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The camera is close on Michelle's head which is moving ba forth. We pull back to reveal Aaron. They are doing it standing up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's taking you so long?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I just started.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You want this baby as much me. Come on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm trying.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If I didn't want you to come, you would have done it five minutes ago.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do I have to do this today? The door opens and a HOUSEKEEPER sticks her head in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who's picking up Uncle Russell?-- Aaron and Elaine quickly pull apart. As the Housekeeper s back out into the hall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh shit, Uncle Russell. Aaron fixes his pants as he exits the room.

dialogues.speaker: DAY
dialogues.text: Norman's cell phone RINGS. He answers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello?... How are you?... Okay..

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I need you to pick up Uncle Russell.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uncle Russell?! Damn! He's always in a bad mood.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's not a mood if he's always in it. It's his personality. Can you do it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alright... 'Alright. I'll do it. See you soon. Bye. Norman hangs up irritated.

dialogues.speaker: A FREEWAY
dialogues.text: We see Norman's car exiting the freeway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aaron and Michelle are standing to the side as the undert place the coffin on the stand. Brian nervously lifts the lid and Aaron looks inside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So is this your father?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on, man. You know that's my father.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just trying to be professional. What up, Michelle?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brian.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He closes the lid and all four undertakers quietly head o Aaron looks up and sees his mother, Cynthia, has entered room. Cynthia is clearly drained and tired. She stares at coffin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mom, how are you feeling?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There were so many things we wanted to do... We were going to go to China.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: China? You don't even like Chinese food.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's not the point. I haven't been feeling good. Who knows how long I'm going to live without him. It happens all the time. One spouse goes and then the next. I mean, it might be different if I had a grandchild to take my mind off of everything.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cynthia, I-- They all cross to the coffin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (cuts Michelle off) Come on, Mom. You're healthy. You'll be fine. You've got your friends and family... Cynthia, Aaron and Michelle stand around the coffin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where is Ryan? Have you heard from him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He'll be here soon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just seeing that boy's face makes me feel better. I've missed him so much. My baby.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She looks down at the coffin. Aaron turns away frustrated Michelle gently touches the coffin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you need anything, Cynthia?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, you can get your hand off my husband's coffin. You're leaving smudge marks. Michelle tries to wipe it off with her sleeve.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MUSIC: "PAPER PLANE" by M.I.A. Elaine and Oscar are walking up the stairs of a typical c apartment building.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The music is coming from Jeff's speakers. JEFF, dressed f funeral, sits at his desk. He's holding a pill bottle tha says: "VALIUM."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, I found them. The ones in the Valium bottle?... Yeah... I'll get them to you this evening... Can't do this afternoon... It's your fault you left them here... I've got a funeral... My uncle died... Yeah, tragic... No, I haven't taken any. I saw what they did to you... What are they anyway?... The doorbell rings.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've gotta go, my sister's here... I'll take them with me and stop by after the funeral... Bye. The doorbell rings again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hang on! Jeff stands up and we see that he's only half dressed for funeral. He doesn't have any pants on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He puts the bottle on the counter then crosses to the doo lets Elaine and Oscar inside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, what's up?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you always open the door half naked? Come on, Jeff. We're going to be late.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've just got to put my pants on and I'm ready. Oscar is still a little shaky.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is he okay?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oscar's freaked out. A guy on a bike ran into the car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It came out of nowhere. I didn't see him. I'm sorry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's okay, baby. (then to Jeff) Go put your damn pants on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm going. I'm going. Jeff heads off to the bathroom and closes the door. Elain spots the bottle of Valium on the table and picks it up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here. Take this..: It'll calm you down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's just Valium. (gets a glass of water) I used to take them all the time... It'll make you feel better, promise.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you sure? I mean, I've got to drive.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It'll be okay. I'll drive, honey. Come on, open wide. She pops the pill in his mouth and hands him some water. swallows. Jeff returns wearing pants.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ready. Let's do it. Oscar and Elaine leave, Jeff surreptitiously picks up the bottle, puts it in his pocket, then follows them out.

dialogues.speaker: INT/EXT. ENTRY WAY
dialogues.text: CAMERA is in the entry way now shooting outside. A TOWN C exits, leaving Ryan in front of the house. RYAN, Aaron's younger brother is taller, more confident, and more succe He moves slowly towards CAMERA and through the front door CAMERA PULLS BACK with him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello! Mom!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Michelle, Aaron and Cynthia are on the couch as Ryan ente living room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ryan! Cynthia runs over to Ryan and flings her arms around him. looks a bit lost in the background with Michelle but they over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know this is hard, Mom. But you're going to be okay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You always know exactly what to say, Ryan. I'm so glad you're here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm always here for you, Mom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I guess if people died every week, we'd see you all the time. Ryan turns to Aaron and Michelle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aaron, how are you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm alright.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How was the flight?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay. I had to buy the seat next to me because I don't trust the airlines with my bags. And there was a lot of turbulence... I guess that's the thing about flying first class. It doesn't matter how much you pay if the plane crashes, you still end up dead-- uh... Ryan realizes what he's said and stops speaking abruptly. too much for Cynthia who rushes upstairs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "End up dead"?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh damn.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll make sure she's okay. Michelle heads off upstairs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see Norman's car turn into "Lakeview Retirement Commun He drives past the sign and through a gate.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Norman is driving behind three OLD LADIES on mobile chair He's honking at them. He finally sees Uncle Russell.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There he is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You didn't tell me the guy was in a wheelchair. UNCLE RUSSELL, an elderly man in a wheelchair, sits in hi chair. Norman drives forward and stops alongside the old man. He down his window and speaks very slowly with a huge smile face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello, Uncle Russell. How are you? We're here to take you to the funeral.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where the fuck have you been, you fat bastard? You're late. If you took any longer I'd be dead, too. The fake smile falls off Norman's face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ryan sees the coffin and slowly heads over with Aaron tra behind. He stands over the coffin. It finally registers t his DAD is actually in there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's hard to see Dad like this. But he's in a better place now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When does dead beat sick?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I guess you're right. This is why I try not to get close to people. There's too much emotion involved.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well that explains why you never call.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you want me to say? Some families talk to each other all the time, some just see each other at funerals. That's us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I guess it is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ryan takes a seat in one of the chairs flanking the coffi Aaron sits as well.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: By the way, I'm going to need that money.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What money?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The money for all this... the funeral. You're supposed to pay half.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What about the insurance?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's Mom's money.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What about the pension?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's Mom's money.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So we're spliting the cost.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are we?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. We are.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, okay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't have it right now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you mean, you don't have it? You just bought a first class seat for your bag.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And that's why I don't have any cash.

dialogues.speaker: DAY
dialogues.text: Elaine is now driving, Oscar is sitting in the passenger looking a little spaced out, with Jeff in the back. Jeff leans forward.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So, poor old Uncle Eddie...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. But he was sick for so long. He's much better off now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dead? Since when does dead beat sick?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shut up, Jeff. Jeff turns his attention to Oscar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I love when you come to family functions, Oscar. Because then Dad focuses all his hate on you. There's no response from Oscar. He looks distantly out th window. The pills are starting to kick in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oscar?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Was there a dog in here just now? Elaine looks at Oscar very-strangely.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What? He sniffs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dalmatian? No, Schnauzer... A beat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What the hell are you talking about? Oscar falls silent and just goes back to looking out the

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uncle Russell is asleep in the back. Norman is looking fo parking space, but the street and long driveway are packe cars. A catering truck and flower van are taking up a lot space.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's nowhere to park. Then the small flower delivery van pulls out. Derek point the newly empty space.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That truck is pulling out. Park there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alright. Just as he's about to drive in, another car takes it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What the hell?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Norman gets out of the car. The other car contains Jeff, and Elaine. Jeff gets out first followed by Elaine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Elaine, I was going to park there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you family, Norman?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, no, but I'm like family.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No such thing. Derek leans out the window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi, Elaine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you doing here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your father invited me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh please. She grabs Oscar and heads to the house followed by Jeff.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Norman gets back into his car. Uncle Russell stirs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's happening?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you see that?... She totally blew me off. The flower delivery van has been waiting to move forward. driver beeps the horn.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I said what's happening? Are we there?. Norman turns around and looks at Uncle Russell.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aw, damn. I have Uncle Russell. How could I forget about Uncle Russell? Derek has other concerns and the van beeps again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to the Van) Yeah, alright!!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What the hell is going on? Uncle Russell pokes Norman with his cane.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: .barely even looked.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Norman, now highly irritated, is forced to drive backward

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oscar, Elaine and Jeff are walking to the house as other arrive.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's very green here, isn't it?... Green... Very green... Very... green. Elaine takes Oscar to the side.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oscar, are you alright?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you mean?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All this talking about phantom dogs and things being green... What's going on?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you talking about? I' fine . Never been greener. Oscar wanders off, leaving Elaine with Jeff.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Elaine, what's wrong with Oscar?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know. Something's not right... ANGLE ON: Oscar as he wanders around the yard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think it's the Valium.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Valium?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I gave him a Valium at your place. I think he's just not used to it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jeff's face reveals his realization of what's happened. H walks off, leaving Elaine watching Oscar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Norman's car is almost at the corner still being forced backwards by the flower van. We see that Derek is still l his own thoughts. Uncle Russell is poking at Norman with his cane.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're going the wrong way!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ow! That hurts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stop the car, Norman.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stop the car. I have to speak with her. I have to speak with Elaine. Norman reluctantly stops the car. Derek gets out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What about Uncle Russell? I need help with Uncle Russell! It's too late. Derek is gone. The van in front of Norman the horn.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's going on here? Where are we?! We're going to be late! Russell hits him on the arm with his cane.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ow! Can you please stop doing that?! The van keeps beeping. Norman backs up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ryan is standing with Aaron. They greet the mourners.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nice to see you again. The mourner shakes hands with Ryan then walks away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who are all these people? I don't even recognize half of them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's your family. You don't recognize them from the last funeral? Ryan looks around the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So what side of the family is he on?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The guy in the leather jacket. Ryan looks around the room and sees a FOUR FOOT SIX MAN ( approaching the coffin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have no idea. Maybe a friend of Dad's from work or something. Aaron turns to Ryan.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So, you're telling me I'm going to have to pay for the whole funeral?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No I'm telling you you'll have the money in a few months when I get my advance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not a God damn credit agency! REVEREND DAVIS, a very calm, serene woman, suddenly appea

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aaron, how are you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, um... We're just waiting for everyone to arrive, then we can get going. I know you're in a hurry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, I have two more funerals and a Christening. I don't know what it is about the Spring, but they're either coming in or going out. She laughs, but Aaron and Ryan just look at her. Reverend stands there waiting to be introduced to Ryan.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have you met my brother, Ryan?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ah, the writer, of course. I must admit I squeezed this job in because I wanted to meet you. I'm reading "Mama's Secret" right now. Don't tell anybody, I'm not supposed to be reading that kind of stuff.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sure the Lord will forgive you. Aaron is irritated.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You must be very proud of your big brother. He really made something of his life.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't wait to hear your eulogy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, no, I'm doing the eulogy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh. I thought...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aaron is the oldest. The reverend tries her best not to look disappointed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Great... Well, I'll just make sure have everything I need.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She looks at the coffin and then at the Bible in her hand

dialogues.speaker: REVEREND DAVIS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: We've got a body and a Bible. Well, I'm all set. She walks off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, I think you should do the eulogy. Everyone's expecting you to do it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, they're not. You're the oldest. You should do it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look most of the people are here for Dad, but let's not kid ourselves. A lot of them are here to hear your eulogy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So imagine how surprised they'll be when they hear yours. Ryan walks away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cynthia is helping prepare the food to go.out. Michelle i the background at the sink. DUNCAN, Cynthia's brother, a aged doctor, approaches.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How's my little sister?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm trying to hold it together, Duncan. He was a really good husband. My friends always told me about the crap their husbands put them through. I never had to deal with any of that. Remember when Uncle Matt got that nanny pregnant?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That was horrible.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They don't make 'em like my Edward anymore. A good husband and a great father to two healthy, strong boys. Michelle cringes in the background.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll make you a cup of coffee, Cynthia.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Coffee can do many things Michelle, but it can't bring back the dead. Beat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tea?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aaron finds a quiet place in the hallway and pulls out hi notes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "My father was an exceptional man... My father was an exceptional man... My father was an exceptional man..." Michelle approaches him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Honey, we still need to finish that thing. Remember today is the last day.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can we talk about this when there's a little less death in the air?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. No we can't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Honey, I'm just not in the mood...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't have any panties on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What? You don't have any panties on? It's my father's funeral.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm just trying to help you out. I'll put them back on before the service starts. Now come on. They turn. Aaron looks around the corner into the living and sees the four foot six man standing by a table. Aaron Michelle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Babe, don't make it obvious, but that guy in the leather jacket standing by the wall. Don't look. Don't look. Don't look. Michelle catches a glimpse of the guy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you recognize him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Isn't that the guy from the Home Depot?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, I don't think so. Don't look. Don't look.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did he put in the cable?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, no, that's not it. He keeps looking at me. Don't look. Don't look.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's probably just a friend of your father's. I'll meet you in the garage. We have a few minutes before Uncle Russell gets here. Michelle walks off. Aaron peeks around the corner again a makes eye contact with the four foot six inch man, who se be staring straight at him. Aaron averts his eyes and hea off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Norman parks the car and gets out. He goes to the trunk a removes the wheelchair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you doing?! Be careful with that. Uncle Russell bangs his cane on the floor impatiently.

dialogues.speaker: UNCLE RUSSELL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Hurry up, we're late. Norman slams the trunk closed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aaron tries to get across the room as Michelle heads into kitchen. Ryan stops Aaron.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, Ryan can you keep an eye out--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: God damn, that Martina has grown up. ANGLE ON: MARTINA, nineteen and attractive.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you talking about Little Martina?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She was like a teenager when I left, and now she's... you know. She's like damn. Aaron looks distastefully at his brother.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can you keep an eye out for Uncle Russell?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think I should go see how she's been.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, why don't you do that? See if she wants a juice box.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ryan heads off towards Martina. Aaron continues across th room.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK, (O.S.)
dialogues.text: Hi there. Aaron turns and finds himself cornered by Frank.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was really sorry to hear about your dad. He talked about you a lot. I saw your wedding pictures. Your wife's dress was very beautiful. Aaron is a little uncomfortable.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh... thanks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did he ever mention me?... Frank? Frank steps forward and holds out his hand. Aaron shakes

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank?... I don't think so, no... Were you a friend of his?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Something like that, yeah. Michelle sticks her head out of the kitchen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Honey. Can I see you for a moment?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, nice to meet you. Thanks for coming. Aaron walks away, leaving Frank alone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WIDE SHOT: Norman struggles to push Uncle Russell up a hi

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on, put your back into it. You're supposed to be a young man. Don't you have any strength?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aaron has almost made it across the room when he is inter by Reverend Davis.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think we should get started. really have to leave at three.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure. Can we just wait five minutes for my Uncle Russell? We can't start without him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: .Of course.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Elaine and Jeff are talking to some mourners.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's so nice to see you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm so sorry to hear about your uncle. But he's in a better place now. I hear Ryan is doing the eulogy. Oscar, carrying a leaf, interrupts the conversation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look... Isn't it beautiful? He wanders off again. Elaine doesn't know what the hell i going on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Elaine, can I speak to you for a minute?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to the mourner) I'll see you inside. Jeff takes Elaine's arm with some urgency and moves off t side.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What? What is it?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have to tell you something and, I'm warning you in advance, you're not going to like it. Elaine looks at Jeff concerned.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aaron is intercepted again by Duncan who is talking to Ry

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aaron. How are we doing on time?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As soon as Uncle Russell gets here we'll be ready to start.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So what's this I hear about Ryan not doing the eulogy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was just telling him how much I'm looking forward to hearing your eulogy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's a shame. I mean, I'm sure you'll be good, Aaron. It's just with Ryan being the writer of the family...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There are people here that don't even know your father. They just came to hear Ryan.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Would you excuse me? Aaron walks away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So any new books coming out? I just finished "Black Hurt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aaron closes the door behind him. Michelle is waiting. Th start kissing and pulling at each other's clothes. Aaron and leans on the door and sighs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you alright?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Every single person wants Ryan to do the eulogy. He was my father, too. I'm supposed to do the damn eulogy! I'm the oldest. Where was Ryan when I was taking care of Dad?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Calm down. Calm down. Forget about everyone. You're going to do the eulogy and it's going to be the best eulogy anyone's every heard. Now could you please do me a favor and get me pregnant?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on, do I have to do this today?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. What do you want? You want me to talk dirty? I'm gonna suck it. I'm gonna to suck it. Before Michelle can continue her PG rated dirty talk, the knock on the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is there more soda in here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes! Come in! Michelle is frustrated.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Elaine is looking at Jeff in absolute shock.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you mean it's not Valium?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I mean what you thought was Valium, wasn't actually Valium. It's a hallucinogenic. Like, acid, mescaline... Special K... Oscar moves in the background behind Elaine and Jeff. Ela looks at him. He's making strange contorted expressions w his face and pointing at the sky. Other people are starti notice him and think he's slightly odd.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This isn't funny, Jeff.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not being funny. Look at him, he's high as a kite! Oscar sticks his head into a huge bush.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What the hell are you doing leaving that stuff around your house?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A friend left it. And who the hell just goes into someone's house and takes pills?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought they were Valium! (takes a deep breath) What am I supposed to do? Should I tell him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, don't do that. It'll just freak him out... We'll just keep a close eye on him, and make sure he doesn't get out of control... And don't let him spend too long talking to one person... or bush. Oscar wanders into the front door. Elaine quickly follows Jeff reluctantly follows Elaine. Derek arrives in time to this and follows as well.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oscar wanders in, followed by Elaine and Jeff. Duncan see enter and approaches them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi, Dad. How are you? She gives him a kiss.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not bad considering we're at a funeral. Jeff steps forward.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi, Dad. He shakes his hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How's Pepperdine treating you? Is Professor Clarke still giving you a hard time?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, no. It's all worked out. Don't worry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not worried about you. Duncan looks pointedly at Elaine, irritating her. Duncan at Oscar who is in the background.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So I see you brought your friend.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's my boyfriend. And you know his name. Derek approaches.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doctor, how nice to see you again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Derek. How are you doing at the hospital?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Great. Great. We should have lunch soon. I'd love to hear what you think about the new pediatric wing at Cedar's.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Definitely. Maybe Elaine would like to join us for lunch? They both look expectantly at Elaine who looks away disgu Cynthia comes up to them and kisses Elaine and Jeff hello Oscar stares at her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Elaine... Jeff... good to see you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm so sorry, Auntie. We're going to miss Uncle Edward so much.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. He was a great guy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oscar, this is my Aunt-- Oscar grabs Cynthia in a tight hug.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm so sorry about... the death... He sings "Amazing Grace" softly as Duncan, Derek, Jeff an Elaine look on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Amazing Grace / How sweet the sound / That saved a wretch like me... Cynthia untangles herself from Oscar. She heads back outs Duncan gives Elaine a look, then heads off after Cynthia.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you going to do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know. I can't leave. Aunt Cynthia would never speak to me again. Jeff notices that Oscar has left. He rushes outside. Elai follows. Derek follows suit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see Oscar emerging from the front doorway followed by Then comes Elaine. Jeff approaches Oscar and stands with him as Elaine watch the doorway. Derek walks up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You look nice, Elaine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm dressed for a funeral.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, but you make death look sexy. She looks at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So, I heard about the engagement.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, hey. I don't really have time to deal with whatever happened between you and me. But I have not told my dad yet, so I would appreciate it if you would keep your mouth shut.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure. Anything for you. Derek looks over and notices Oscar looking bewildered.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So that's him? That's the man you're going to spend the rest of your life with? Elaine looks over at the drugged up Oscar. Oscar leans ov like he's on a nod. Jeff leans down with him, watching. R before Oscar falls over, he comes up really fast.- Then h starts walking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yep, that's him. Oscar who has been walking in circles with a look of awe face, changes direction and flies by Elaine and Derek bac the house with Jeff in tow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Elaine., I- Elaine follows the guys, leaving Derek behind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aaron is straightening his tie and practicing his eulogy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My father was an exceptional man... My father was-- Frank again approaches Aaron.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Actually, there's something I'd like to talk to you about... when you have a minute. Aaron hears Uncle Russell in the background.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, that's great. Do you mind if we do it later though? My uncle just got here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure. Aaron heads off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Norman pushes Russell up the stairs close to where Derek standing. He looks like he's about to collapse from exhau Norman lets go of the wheelchair and catches his breath. grabs the chair blocking Norman from view just as Aaron a

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you, Derek, you're a life saver. Hope it wasn't too much trouble.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No problem at all. Aaron wheels Uncle Russell inside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How are you doing, Uncle Russell?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Terrible. Derek follows, leaving Norman standing there out of breat

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can I get a little help?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aaron enters and nods to Reverend Davis, who stands at th front.

dialogues.speaker: REVEREND.DAVIS
dialogues.text: Ladies and gentlemen, could you all kindly take your seats? We're about to begin the service. Ryan helps Martina to her seat. Jeff keeps an eye on Osca Elaine grabs Oscar and drags him to a seat. Aaron wheels Russell to his place.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Move! Move! He pokes people with his cane. Aaron then takes his seat Michelle. Oscar is not looking so good. Ryan finally ends the conversation with Martina and heads seat. Reverend Davis is about to start, but waits as Norman, sw pushes through the crowd to his seat. The reverend waits the disturbance to end, so Norman attracts the attention everyone. Norman takes his seat next to Derek. Derek lean away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You stink.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Family and friends, we're gathered here today to mourn the passing of Edward Barnes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, well, you left me to push Uncle Russell up that damn hill all by myself. Then took all the credit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Elaine, turns around.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Norman, shut up. Elaine turns back around. Norman is irritated by this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'd like to start with a favorite passage of Edwards from First Samuel chapter 18, verses 1-4 in the King James Bible.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "And it came to pass, when he had made an end of speaking unto Saul, that the soul of Jonathan was knit with the soul of David, and Jonathan loved him as his own soul. And Saul took him that day, and would let him go no more home to his father's house..." While the reverend is talking, Norman pokes Elaine on the shoulder and leans forward.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, Elaine, I know you don't think I'm part of the family--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'Cause you're not.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: .but when you dissed me back there, I had Uncle Russell in the car. Aaron, disturbed by Norman's whispering, looks over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You stole my parking space, and I had to push him half a mile up a hill. We almost missed the service! Aaronlooks over again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, Norman, if you poke me one more time, I'm going to kick your ass.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What the hell is going on?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She stole my parking space!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (whispers to Norman) Stole your parking space?!. My father's dead! Act right. Reverend Davis looks at them then continues her speech.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ."Then Jonathan and David made a covenant, because he loved him as his own soul..." As she speaks, Norman looks at his wrist, worried. The wo sitting next to him smacks his wrist down. ANGLE ON: Elaine looks at Jeff who watches Oscar. Oscar i fidgeting and looking worried. ANGLE ON: Aaron and Michelle. Aaron looks worried.

dialogues.speaker: REVEREND DAVIS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: ."And Jonathan stripped himself of the robe that was upon him, and gave it to David, and his garments, even to his sword and to his bow, and to his girdle." ANGLE ON: Oscar is laughing. Elaine tries to control him.

dialogues.speaker: REVEREND DAVIS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: And now we'll have a few words from Edward's son, Aaron. Ryan's older brother. ANGLE ON: Aaron as he gathers himself. Michelle gives Aar supportive squeeze of the arm. Aaron looks over and sees staring at him. ANGLE ON: Uncle Russell.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why isn't Ryan doing the eulogy? This is bullshit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aaron arrives at the front and looks out across the expec crowd. He's extremely nervous.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good afternoon, everyone. (his voice cracks) Thank you for coming... I never realized Dad was so popular. It looks like he's got more friends now that he's dead. Blank faces stare back at Aaron. Cynthia looks pained. Everyone is silent except for Oscar who laughs loudly. El silences him with a look. Aaron composes himself and pull notes out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My father was an exceptional man... He was born in 1938. He grew up in Alabama on a farm. He loved to take long walks in the woods with his close friend, Bobby. He told me how they spent their summer days riding their bikes through the fields and swimming in the lake. As Aaron speaks, Reverend Davis looks concerned because t eulogy is so bad. She looks to Ryan who looks like "what do?" Jeff looks more concerned with Oscar, whose face is conto with pain. He looks like he's going to burst. ANGLE ON: Aaron.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dad's first job was working after school as an assistant to an electrician named Mr. Thompson. Back then, Blacks weren't allowed to wear rubber gloves. So my father got shocked a lot. Because of that, he had no feeling in his fingertips. I asked my Dad what his first boss was like... The drugs have gotten the best of Oscar. He suddenly grab Elaine's arm. Aaron keeps talking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you just see that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: See what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The coffin just moved.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm telling you I saw it move. Aaron becomes vaguely aware of the disturbance, but battl with his eulogy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: .He said he was a nice man, and surprisingly well dressed. When Dad was eighteen, he left home after an argument with his father. He never told me what that argument was about, but I do know that after leaving South Carolina, sadly he and Bob lost touch and never saw each other again. Dad went to college where he studied accounting, a decision which lead to a career in corporate finance... But his real passion was for the arts, with a particular fondness for theatre, dance and musicals. He was a charter member of the Negro Ensemble Company and contributed regularly to the Alvin Ailey School of Dance. Oscar's protests are getting louder. Duncan looks back at disruption with a disapproving glare. Elaine looks at Jef watches, concerned.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There, look. It happened again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oscar, please- People start looking at Oscar, who's becoming increasingl vocal, and looking increasingly like someone on acid.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That coffin's moving!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oscar. Just calm down. Aaron looks over to Oscar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The coffin's moving! Michelle looks worried. Cynthia watches silently. Oscar j up. Aaron stops the eulogy. Elaine is about to die from embarrassment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's someone alive in there!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oscar, please sit down. Oscar ignores her and walks purposefully towards the coff People watch him in astonishment, including Jeff.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What the hell is wrong with you people?! Oscar approaches the coffin as Aaron steps off the dais. tries to hold Oscar back, but she can't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oscar, where are you going?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you doing?

dialogues.text: There's someone moving in there. Can't you see? Oscar tries to open the coffin. Aaron and Elaine try to restrain him, but can't. A tussle begins. Ryan jumps in t help.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What the hell is wrong with you?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ryan, no!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Elaine attempts to grab Ryan. Duncan stands up and tries help.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get away from there!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, I have to show you! He's alive! He's alive! The scene descends into absolute chaos with people pushin struggling. Finally, the coffin falls off the platform an over. The dead body of Edward rolls out onto the floor at the f Cynthia. Cynthia screams. Aaron freezes in shock. Michelle takes Cynthia through th kitchen. The living room is left in chaos.

dialogues.text: Elaine drags Oscar out the back. Jeff follows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's alright, Cynthia. It's alright. She sits in a chair crying uncontrollably. Aaron is so an he just marches out.

dialogues.text: Some MEN grab the body and put it back in the coffin. Aar comes out of the kitchen and heads to the back yard. As t put the coffin back on the stand, Ryan addresses the crow

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please let me extend my apologies to you all. I understand the incident you just witnessed was quite shocking, but everything will be... returned... to it's proper place. Please enjoy the refreshments, and we'll call you when we're ready to continue.

dialogues.text: It wouldn't have happened if Ryan had done the eulogy. Aaron exits through the garden door.

dialogues.text: Aaron storms out to Elaine who is trying to comfort Oscar looking very disturbed. Jeff is also there, looking guilt

dialogues.text: Elaine, what the hell was that?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm so sorry, Aaron.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, okay. My dead father's sprawled out on the living room floor, but it's okay, you're sorry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But the coffin was moving.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please, Aaron. Go back inside. I'll explain later. An annoyed and confused Aaron turns and walks back to the He's almost to the door when Michelle arrives.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, I haven't made the call about the down payment yet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wasn't going to say that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No I'm not going to have sex with you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wasn't going to say that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What were you going to say?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi. He goes inside leaving Michelle standing there. Duncan co out and heads for Oscar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll kill him! Elaine tries to keep Duncan away from Oscar, who is stres enough and looks terrified.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dad, leave it alone!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Leave it alone?! He just knocked my brother-in-law out of his coffin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It wasn't his fault.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes it was. My sister is in tears. I can't believe you brought this idiot! I don't ever want to see him again, do you understand me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't do that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why not?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because we're... moving in together. Duncan looks over at Oscar, who looks like he's just seen ghost. He's struggling to stand up straight, with Jeff wh doing his best to look after him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you crazy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dad, this isn't actually what he's like. He took some drugs and--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Drugs?! Is he on the pipe?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jeff looks over, his eyes pleading with Elaine not to tel him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No he's not on the pipe. He took some Valium and had a.bad reaction. Jeff looks grateful.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Valium?! That's not a Valium high. Your mother was on Valium for forty years. She never knocked over a coffin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dad, please.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I just want to point out that you won't see Derek knocking over a coffin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not right now, Dad.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fine. I've got to check on Cynthia, but this isn't over. Duncan walks back to the house. Elaine walks over to Osca is hugging a tree.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oscar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Elaine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come and sit down.

dialogues.text: Aaron talks to a mourner. Norman comes up and hugs him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you alright?... That was insane. He just fell out the coffin like a dead fish. I guess its not much of a metaphor when you're talking about a dead human, but--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Death at a Funeral 02/6/0.9 49.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aaron looks at Norman.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Norman, please.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh yeah... Sorry. It's just that you never know when it's your time. Like, I have this weird thing on my wrist. I've had it for a few weeks now. I don't know what it is--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why don't you show it to my Uncle Duncan? He's a doctor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He is? Great. Thanks. Norman walks off toward the kitchen. He passes Uncle Russ and Ryan talking to Martina.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I read your last book, "Black Hurt."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good, good. Thanks a lot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not giving you a compliment you arrogant bastard. What a load of bullshit. I wouldn't wipe my ass with it. Ryan leads Martina away from Uncle Russell.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oscar, Elaine and Jeff are standing together.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I swear it was moving. I must be losing my mind... (looks at his hands) Why are my hands so big?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oscar, listen to me. I need to tell you something... Elaine sits him down on the bench.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now... You remember I gave you some Valium earlier?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well it turns out that it wasn't actually Valium. Oscar just looks at Elaine. Jeff slinks off into the background.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can you hear me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cynthia is being comforted by her friends and Duncan. Nor enters and beckons Duncan over to the side.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello, Doctor, I know this is a bad time, but I've got this thing on my hand. I've had it for weeks now... Duncan is looking at Norman incredulously.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you think it is? Cynthia stands up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Duncan, I'm going back now. She exits. Reluctantly, Duncan answers Norman.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You should probably go see a dermatologist. He turns to follow his sister out, but Norman pulls him b

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Really? Why? What do you think it is?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know. It looks like some kind of pigment mutation. Duncan walks further out of the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pigment mutation?! Duncan turns again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're probably just allergic to something. Maybe from shellfish, nuts... Duncan heads further out of the room, but Norman won't gi

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nuts? What kind of nuts? Duncan turns around again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know. Pecans? Peanuts?... Excuse me. Duncan finally exits, leaving Norman looking shocked and terrified.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A pigment mutation?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Elaine is trying to explain to Oscar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you understand? Hallucinogenic. Oscar recoils. He turns to Jeff.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, now, the best thing to do is relax and just go with the flow. Try and enjoy it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oscar stands up, panicked and grabs Jeff by the lapels. W the bottle of "Valium" falls out of his pocket.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oscar! She tries to pull him off Jeff.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How long does it last?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know... eight hours?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eight hours?! Of this?!!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oscar let go. She pulls him off Jeff. ANGLE ON: Derek watching from the window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm going to be sick. ANGLE ON: Derek smoothing his hair seeing his opportunity ANGLE ON: Oscar runs inside. Elaine follows with Jeff in

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oscar! Come back. They head into the house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Derek has been looking at Elaine outside and waiting for moment. Elaine comes rushing in following Oscar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, hi, Elaine. You following me? She just runs right past, then Jeff rushes past following Elaine. Oscar pushes through people.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Excuse me. Sorry. Excuse me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Elaine grabs Oscar and leads him to the stairs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Excuse me. He's going to be sick. They head up the stairs with Jeff following.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Elaine rounds the corner and leads Oscar to the bathroom. goes in and shuts the door behind him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oscar is building up quite a sweat and mumbling to himsel catches his reflection in the mirror and SCREAMS! Elaine the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oscar. Oscar grabs the hair-dryer and wields it like a gun.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stand back!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oscar, put down the dryer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get back or I'll blow your head off. Oscar backs Elaine out of the bathroom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oscar, please-- Oscar shuts the door and locks it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Elaine is pressed against the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oscar, are you okay? She tries to open the door, but it's locked. Jeff walks u checking his pockets.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oscar, let me in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jeff realizes he lost the pill bottle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oscar. Oscar?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh... Elaine... I can't find the pill bottle? But Elaine is too busy to hear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oscar! Open the door. Jeff looks at the floor as he leaves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oscar is talking to himself in the mirror.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay. Breathe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's going to be okay. Breathe. You're and investment banker. You've handled mergers for billion dollar companies. You can do this. Dead bodies don't move. They don't move. But that body was moving. It was moving. Then he slaps himself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Snap out of it! You can handle this. You can do this. He runs the tap and splashes some water on his face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alright. You're okay. Stay calm... Stay calm... Oscar is still staring at himself in the mirror.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's it, Oscar, keep it together. K.I.T. Keep it together. K.I.T. Keep it together. Everything's going to be fine. Nothing moved. Dead people don't move. They're stiff. They don't move, do they?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (he screams at himself in the

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Elaine has her ear pressed against the door. She hears th scream.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Easy now. Easy now. We can do this. A few hours. That's nothing. No sweat. I mean you've already been in here for... He looks at his watch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where's my watch?! He sees it's on the other wrist.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh! He checks the time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's already been...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Elaine continues to knock on the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Open the door. Oscar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oscar finally gets a read on his watch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Five minutes. Suddenly the pressure of. the situation overtakes him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: God damn! Shit! Shit! Shit! Shit!

dialogues.text: As the screaming and cursing goes on upstairs, Aaron appr a mourner who looks concerned.

dialogues.speaker: OSCAR, (O.S.)
dialogues.text: Shit! Shit! Shit! Shit! Shit!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's alright. Aaron turns around not knowing what to do.
